[[Republic of Ireland]] | death_date = | death_place = | medium = Writer, comedian, stand up | nationality = | active = 1982–present | genre = Topical comedy, [[religious satire|religious]] and [[political satire]] | subject = [[Atheism]], [[free speech]] | influences = | influenced = | spouse = | notable_work = | signature = | website = [http://www.patcondell.net/ www.patcondell.net] }} '''Patrick Condell''' (born 23 November 1949) is a writer, polemicist, and former [[stand-up comedy|stand-up comedian]]. In his early career he wrote and performed in [[alternative comedy]] shows during the 1980s and 1990s in London, winning the [[Time Out Comedy Awards|Time Out Comedy Award]] in 1991. He was also formerly a regular panelist on [[BBC Radio 1]]'s ''Loose Talk'' programme. In early 2007 he began uploading on to the [[internet]] short filmed [[monologue]] [[polemic]]s primarily about religious authority, [[authoritarianism]] in government and [[left-wing politics]], and the societal effects of [[Muslim]] immigration into Europe, which have featured on the front pages of websites such as [[YouTube]] and [[LiveLeak]]. They have also been published on DVD, and also as a book of video transcripts. As of June 2017 Condell's YouTube channel has over a third of a million subscribers, with over 70 million views.{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/patcondell/about|title=Pat Condell|last=|first=|date=|website=YouTube|access-date=26 May 2017}} ==Early life== Condell was born in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]{{cite video |people=Pat Condell |date=17 August 2010 |title=An Irish joke |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZmxMlSTETo |publisher=YouTube |time=1:08 |quote=I was born in Ireland |accessdate=20 August 2010}} and raised in England as a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]].{{cite web |last=Hay |first=Malcolm |title=Pat Condell: interview |publisher=Time Out London |date=3 November 2006 |url=http://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/pat-condell-interview |accessdate=20 August 2010|quote=Condell’s 56. He was born an [[Irish Catholic]] but educated in [[Church of England]] schools.}} His father was a [[Problem gambling|compulsive gambler]] working in a betting shop until he was sent to prison for stealing money; he then died of [[leukaemia]]. The Condell family in consequence was impoverished, moving repeatedly from home to home. He was educated in several different Church of England schools in [[South London]]; saying of this time: "I found myself segregated in assembly and shunted into another room while everyone said their morning prayers. The whole pantomime seemed hollow to me even then. Once you become aware of the gulf between what people profess to believe and how they actually behave, it’s hard to take any of it seriously." Condell left school at 16, his first job being a dish-washer in the revolving restaurant on top of the Post Office Tower, now known as the [[BT Tower]] in London, for five shillings an hour. He became a [[vegetarian]] in 1976 after watching a deer being butchered.{{cite web | last = Condell | first = Pat | title = Q & A Godless Comedy | publisher = patcondell.net | url = http://www.patcondell.net/q-a/ | accessdate = 11 May 2014 | quote = I became a vegetarian in 1976 while watching a deer being butchered.}} Condell did a number of jobs including six years of logging in Canada. ==Comedy== Condell performed [[alternative comedy]] shows during the 1980s and 1990s in the United Kingdom. His first performance on stage was at the age of 32 in a [[sketch comedy|comedy sketch]] called ''Mountbatten’s Plimsoll''. He also wrote poetry and appeared in the ''Poetry Olympics'' at the [[Young Vic Theatre]] in 1982,{{cite news | title = Poets' marathon at Young Vic 'Olympics' |work=The Times |publisher=Times Digital archive | date = 30 November 1982 |subscription=yes | accessdate = 6 September 2009 | url = http://infotrac.galegroup.com/itw/infomark/976/603/71370334w16/purl=rc2_TTDA_2_condell___11/29/1982+to+11/31/1982______________________________________________________________________________________&dyn=sig!1?sw_aep=uwesteng | last=Foreman | first=Judy }} which led to a job writing weekly poems for the ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' magazine. Condell was described at the time as "a manic gimlet-eyed, crop-haired poet" in ''Drama: The Quarterly Theatre Review book''.{{cite book |title=Drama: The Quarterly Theatre Review |year=1981 |publisher=British Theatre Association |isbn= |page=34 |oclc= 297266816 }} He then performed on the London alternative comedy circuit for several years (originally under the name Eddie Zibin).{{cite web | last = Condell | first = Pat | title = Comedy and Me | publisher =patcondell.net | url = http://www.patcondell.net/about-me/comedy-me/ | accessdate =11 May 2014 }} He also performed at the Tunnel Club, next to the [[Blackwall Tunnel]], where he describes the audience as a "nightmare;" bottles and glasses were thrown at him, and one person attempted to cut the [[microphone]] lead with a pair of garden shears. Condell was a performer at [[The Comedy Store, London|The Comedy Store]] in the Cutting Edge team, with whom he performed at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] in 1991.{{cite web | url = http://special.lib.gla.ac.uk/sta/search/detaile.cfm?EID=23884 | title = STA Catalogue – Event Details | accessdate = 16 March 2009 | publisher = [[University of Glasgow]]}} That year Condell was the winner of a ''[[Time Out Comedy Awards|Time Out Comedy Award]]''.{{cite web | title = Time Out Awards | publisher =Chortle | year = 1991 | url = http://www.chortle.co.uk/features_static/awards/timeout.php | accessdate =22 October 2007 }} From 1991 to 1994 Condell was a regular panellist on BBC Radio 1's "Loose Talk." During the mid-1990s, he was performing over 200 times a year. Due to the late nights and regular travelling he decided to start writing for other comedians, while still doing the occasional performance. In 1991 he performed comedy sketches at [[Duke of York's Theatre]], which were released onto VHS as ''Barf Bites Back!'' (1991).{{cite web | title = Barf Bites Back! (VHS) (1991) | publisher = Amazon.co.uk | url = https://www.amazon.co.uk/Barf-Bites-Back-Tony-Slattery/dp/B00008T3N4 | accessdate = 16 March 2009 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090122213329/http://www.amazon.co.uk/Barf-Bites-Back-Tony-Slattery/dp/B00008T3N4 | archivedate = 22 January 2009}} Condell's 1996 play ''Barry Sorts It Out'' was given a negative review in the ''[[Financial Times]]'', which described it as "a sordid East End comedy" which "repeats ''ad nauseam'' the same gag." The reviewer concluded that it is "a play with all the bite of a set of joke-shop fangs."{{cite web | last = Shuttleworth | first = Ian | authorlink = Ian Shuttleworth | title = The pick of London's second one-person play festival |work=Financial Times | date = 29 October 1996 | url = http://www.cix.co.uk/~shutters/reviews/96089.htm | accessdate =4 February 2008 }} His 2006 stand-up show ''Faith Hope and Sanity'', subtitled "A Few Jokes About Religion Before It Kills Us All," was a platform for his comedy and atheist beliefs. "This is the first time I’ve set out to write a show in order to say something, rather than just as a vehicle for stand-up" he said of the show. He performed the show at London’s [[Etcetera Theatre]].{{cite web | title = As recommended by the Messiah.. | publisher = Chortle.co.uk | date = 11 October 2006 | url = http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2006/11/10/4673/as_recommended_by_the_messiah%85 | accessdate =17 March 2009}}{{cite news | last = Hall | first = Julian | title = James Sherwood: I Know What You Did Last Sunday, Etc Theatre, London |work=The Independent | date = 11 January 2007 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/reviews/james-sherwood-i-know-what-you-did-last-sunday-etc-theatre-london--none-onestar-twostar-threestar-fourstar-fivestar-431663.html | accessdate =17 March 2009}} [[Chortle Awards|''Chortle'']] gave Condell's 2006 show a negative review, noting that Condell is covering familiar territory but "is not quite up to the job," and observing that Condell's material was delivered "with very little variation in pace or tone, ... with the feel of a lecture" and "no structure, no building up to a passionate, climactic conclusion, no ebb and flow of storytelling." ''Chortle'' concluded that "Condell is still going through the motions."{{cite web | title = Pat Condell: "Faith Hope & Sanity" | publisher = Chortle.co.uk | url = ===Atheism=== Richard Dawkins, author of ''[[The God Delusion]]'', said of Condell that "Pat Condell is unique. Nobody can match his extraordinary blend of suavity and savagery. With his articulate intelligence he runs rings around the religious [[wingnut (politics)|wingnuts]] that are the targets of his merciless humour. Thank goodness he is on our side". In 2008, Dawkins's website released a collection of Condell's monologues on DVD, titled ''Pat Condell: Anthology''.{{Cite web |author = Pat Condell |title = Pat Condell: Anthology Feb. 2007–Feb. 2008 |publisher = richarddawkins.net |date = 2008 |url = http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/2517 |accessdate = 27 October 2013 |oclc = 466340767 |postscript = {{inconsistent citations}} |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131029210532/http://old.richarddawkins.net/articles/2517 |archive-date = 29 October 2013 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }} In an interview with the [[Bosnia]]n magazine ''Start'',{{cite web | title = Kontaktirajte Magazinu START | publisher = Magazin Start | url = http://www.startbih.info/kontakt.asp | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080103081733/http://www.startbih.info/kontakt.asp | archivedate = 3 January 2008 | accessdate =18 March 2009}}{{cite web|title=Start Interview List |publisher=Magazin Start |url=http://www.startbih.info/html/258.htm |accessdate=18 March 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Condell says his intent "is to get other people's unprovable beliefs out of my life, and out of government, the law and education. https://web.archive.org/web/20071014212229/http://blog.newhumanist.org.uk/2007/08/comedian-pat-condell-ranting-about.html | archivedate=14 October 2007 | accessdate = 26 March 2009}} ===''No Mosque at Ground Zero''=== {{See also|Park51}} Condell has been resolute and outspoken in his opposition to the development of [[Park51]], near the site of 11 September 2001 [[September 11, 2001 attacks|World Trade Center attack]], in lower Manhattan. On 4 June 2010, he released a video titled "No Mosque at Ground Zero", in which he said that it was representative of Islamic triumphalism and that the United States would soon be on the verge of Islamization and have its freedoms trimmed, as Europe has.{{cite web | last = S. Leiken | first = Robert | title = Why Is This Atheist So Smug? | publisher = Foreign Affairs | date =1 July 2005 | url = http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/60829/robert-s-leiken/europes-angry-muslims | accessdate =13 February 2011}} The video has attracted 6 million views since it was uploaded. Speaking on why he believes the Mosque is offensive, Pat Condell stated: :"To describe it as they have as a tribute to the victims is beyond bad taste, and shows a profound contempt for those who died. It would be hard to find a more provocative gesture short of standing on their graves and burning the American flag. Yet how typical of Islam, with its own hair trigger sensitivity to the slightest imagined insult, to do something so arrogant and insensitive."{{cite web | title = Pat Condell on Ground Zero mosque: "Is it possible to be astonished, but not surprised?" | publisher = [[Jihad Watch]] | date =4 June 2010 | url = http://www.jihadwatch.org/2010/06/pat-condell-on-ground-zero-mosque-is-it-possible-to-be-astonished-but-not-surprised.html | accessdate =13 February 2011}} Additionally, Condell cast some doubt over the funding of the community centre, and claimed that Islam would have been banned in the civilised world if it wasn't for the fact it was a religion. He compared the system of Sharia and the Muslims who endorse it to [[Nazi Germany]]. The video was among the top 10 most discussed YouTube videos of 2010.{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2010/12/21/angry-redheads-rant-is-most-discussed-youtube-video-of-2010-620678/|title=Angry redhead’s rant is most discussed YouTube video of 2010|publisher=[[Metro.co.uk]]|accessdate=10 February 2018|date=21 December 2010}} ===''The Trouble with Islam'' reaction=== [[File:The trouble with Islam.ogv|thumb|right|250px|''The Trouble with Islam'']] {{see also|Counter-jihad}} Condell also received criticism after links to his monologue titled ''The Trouble with Islam'', were circulated to commissioners in the California city of [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]]'s Peace and Justice Commission. Condell said in the video that Islam is "a religion of war", that "Muslim women in Britain who cover their faces are mentally ill", though in some parts of the world women have no choice but to cover their face, as they are "governed...by primitive pigs whose only achievement in life is to be born with a penis in one hand and a [[Qur'an]] in the other". Commissioner Elliot Cohen described Condell's comments as "insulting, degenerating and racist".{{cite web | title = Comic in US 'hate speech' row | publisher =Chortle | date =17 May 2007 | url = http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2007/05/17/5335/comic_in_us_hate_speech_row | accessdate =22 October 2007}} Condell then accused Cohen of being "motivated by his own narrow personal and political agenda which has nothing to do with [Condell] or the video clip". The video was initially sent to them by fellow Peace and Justice Commissioner Jonathan Wornick, who said it "tries to expose intolerance in the [[Muslim world]]", such as "the intolerance of [[Islamism|radical Islamists]] who say if you insult Allah, you should have your head cut off".{{cite web | last =Scherr | first =Judith | title = Commissioners Condemn Bigoted E-Mail | publisher =Berkeley Daily Planet | date =15 May 2007 | url = http://www.ci.berkeley.ca.us/news/print.asp?id=20911 | archiveurl = http://www.berkeleydailyplanet.com/pdfs/05-15-07.pdf | archivedate = 11 September 2009 | accessdate =22 October 2007 }} Condell said that its popularity proves "there is an enthusiastic audience for comedy ideas and opinions which are routinely censored out of existence in the UK’s mainstream media, thanks to misguided [[political correctness]]".{{cite web | last = Duke | first = Barry | title = Condell hits top a million | publisher =[[The Freethinker (journal)|The Freethinker]] | date = 11 August 2007 | url = http://freethinker.co.uk/2007/08/11/condell-hits-top-a-million/ | accessdate =22 October 2007 }} ===YouTube censorship=== {{See also|Criticism of Google#YouTube}} Condell's video ''Welcome to Saudi Britain'' was removed by YouTube early in October 2008, but reinstated shortly after. In it Condell criticises Britain's sanctioning of a [[Sharia]] court, and refers to the entire country of [[Saudi Arabia]] as "mentally ill" for [[Women's rights in Saudi Arabia|its abuse of women]]. A YouTube spokesman said "YouTube has clear policies that prohibit inappropriate content on the site, such as pornography, gratuitous violence or hate speech.... If users repeatedly break these rules we disable their accounts." The [[National Secular Society]] was among the complainants to YouTube, saying "as usual, he (Condell) does not mince his words, but he is not saying anything that is untrue. His main thrust is one of outrage on behalf of those Muslim women who will suffer because they are forced to have their marital problems solved in a male-dominated Sharia court."{{cite web | last = Beckford | first = Martin | title = YouTube censors comedian's anti-Sharia video called 'Welcome to Saudi Britain' |work=The Daily Telegraph | date = 4 September 2008 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/3130883/YouTube-censors-comedians-anti-Sharia-video-called-Welcome-to-Saudi-Britain.html | accessdate =16 March 2009 }} Shortly after, YouTube reversed their earlier decision saying "Upon further review of the context of Pat Condell's comments, we've reinstated it." [[Richard Dawkins]] applauded the reversal, saying "I congratulate YouTube on an excellent decision. Pat Condell is hard-hitting, but always quietly reasonable in tone."{{cite web | last = Dawkins | first = Richard | title = YouTube Reinstates Pat Condell | publisher = Richarddawkins.net | date = 4 September 2008 | url = http://richarddawkins.net/videos/3204-youtube-reinstates-pat-condell | accessdate =24 April 2010}} Condell believed that it was removed due to a flagging campaign by Islamic activists.{{cite news | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110616011021/http://richarddawkins.net/videos/3204-youtube-reinstates-pat-condell | archivedate= 16 June 2011 | first = Carel | last = Brendel | title = Dwarse cabaretier Pat Condell niet verbaasd over opmars van Wilders | url = http://www.hetverraadvanlinks.nl/InterviewCondell.htm | publisher = [[Algemeen Dagblad]] | location = Netherlands | date = 7 March 2009 | accessdate = 17 March 2009 | language = Dutch | quote = }}{{cite web | url = http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=119389495&blogId=475755701 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100208100832/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=119389495&blogId=475755701 |archivedate=8 February 2010 |title = Interview with Dutch newspaper AD Weekend (unedited) | accessdate = 16 March 2009| author = Pat Condell | date = 10 March 2009 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.hetvrijevolk.com/?pagina=8078 | title = Interview met Pat Condell | accessdate = 16 March 2009 | last = Nasser | first = PLodewijk | date = 9 March 2009 | publisher = Het Vrije Volk | language = Dutch }} YouTube also briefly removed Condell's video ''Godless and Free'' but then restored it, emailing Condell and explaining that it had been removed erroneously. ==Works== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" !
